article.title: Bakelite
article.paragraph: Bakelite(IPAc-enˈbeɪkəlaɪtRespellBAYkə-lyt, sometimes spelledBaekelitecite bookSieckhaus, John F.Chemicals, Human Health, and the Environmenthttps://books.google.com/books?idJune 3, 2009Xlibris Corporation978-1-4628-1043-738), orpolyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride, is an earlyplastic. It is athermosetting plasticthermosettingphenol formaldehyde resin, formed from acondensation reactionofphenolwithformaldehyde. It was developed byDemographics of BelgiumBelgian-born chemistLeo BaekelandinNew Yorkin 1907.

One of the firstplasticsmade from synthetic components, Bakelite was used for its electricalnonconductornonconductivityand heat-resistant properties in electricalInsulator (electricity)insulators, radio and telephone casings, and such diverse products askitchenware,jewelry, pipe stems, children'stoys, andfirearms. The "retro" appeal of old Bakelite products has made them collectible.cite bookCookPatrickSlessorCatherineAn illustrated guide to bakelite collectables1998QuantumLondon978186160212123 February 2015

Bakelite was designated aNational Historic Chemical LandmarksNational Historic Chemical Landmarkon November 9, 1993 by theAmerican Chemical Societyin recognition of its significance as the world's first synthetic plastic.cite webAmerican Chemical Society National Historic Chemical LandmarksBakelite: The World’s First Synthetic Plastichttp://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/education/whatischemistry/landmarks/bakelite.html23 February 2015
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: Baekeland was already wealthy, due to his invention of Velox photographic paper, when he began to investigate the reactions of phenol and formaldehyde in his home laboratory. Chemists had begun to recognize that many natural resins and fibres werepolymers. Baekeland's initial intent was to find a replacement forshellac, a material that was in limited supply because it was made naturally from the excretion oflacKerria laccabugs. Baekeland produced a soluble phenol-formaldehyde shellac called "Novolak", but it was not a market success.

Baekeland then began trying to strengthen wood by impregnating it with a synthetic resin, rather than coating it.By controlling the pressure and temperature applied tophenolandformaldehyde, Baekeland produced a hard moldable material which he named "Bakelite".cite newsAmatoIvan Leo Baekeland [[Time (magazine)|Time]]March 29, 1999 http://www.time.com/time/time100/scientist/profile/baekeland.html cite webLeo Baekeland Plastics June 28, 2000 http://www.historylearningsite.co.uk/plastic.htm The first synthetic thermosetting plastic ever made, Baekeland speculated on "the thousand and one... articles" that it could be used to make.rp58–59Baekeland considered the possibilities of using a wide variety of filling materials, including cotton, powdered bronze, and slate dust, but was most successful with wood andasbestosfibers.

Baekeland filed a substantial number of patents in the area.His "Method of making insoluble products of phenol and formaldehyde" was filed on July 13, 1907 and granted on December 7, 1909.US patent reference942699 19091207 Leo H. Baekeland Method of making insoluble products of phenol and formaldehyde Baekeland also filed for patent protection in other countries, including Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Hungary, Japan, Mexico, Russia, and Spain.cite journalMercelisJorisLeo Baekeland’s Transatlantic Struggle for Bakelite: Patenting Inside and Outside of AmericaTechnology and Culture201253Society for the History of Technologyhttp://www.academia.edu/4217504/Leo_Baekeland_s_Transatlantic_Struggle_for_Bakelite_Patenting_Inside_and_Outside_of_America23 February 2015He announced his invention at a meeting of theAmerican Chemical Societyon February 5, 1909.cite newsNew Chemical Substance [[The New York Times]] February 6, 1909 http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?resPDF

link.target: File:First Semi-commercial Bakelizer 1935 Bakelite Review Silver Anniversary p6.tif
link.part: The first semi-commercial Bakelizer, from Baekeland's laboratory

article.paragraph: Baekeland started semi-commercial production of his new material in his home laboratory, marketing it as a material for electrical insulators. By 1910, he was producing enough material to justify expansion. He formed the General Bakelite Company as a U.S. company to manufacture and market his new industrial material. He also made overseas connections to produce materials in other countries.

Bijker gives a detailed discussion of the development of Bakelite and the Bakelite Company's production of various applications of materials.As of 1911, the company's main focus was laminating varnish, whose sales volume vastly outperformed both molding material and cast resin. By 1912, molding material was gaining ground, but its sales volume for the company did not exceed that of laminating varnish until the 1930s.

As the sales figures also show, the Bakelite Company produced "Transparent" cast resin (which did not include filler) for a small ongoing market during the 1910s and 1920s.rp172–174Blocks or rods of cast resin, also known as "artificial amber", were machined and carved to create items such as pipe stems, cigarette holders and jewelry.cite bookEllisCarletonSynthetic resins and their plastics1923The Chemical Catalog Co.New York164–165However, the demand for molded plastics led the Bakelite Company to concentrate on molding, rather than developing market opportunities for cast resins.cite bookThe Fourth Kingdom: The Social Construction of Bakelite101–198BijkerWiebe E.Of bicycles, bakelites, and bulbs : toward a theory of sociotechnical change1997MIT PressCambridge, Mass.97802625222741st MIT Press pbkhttps://books.google.com/books?id2 September 2015rp172–174

The Bakelite Corporation was formed in 1922 (after patent litigation favorable to Baekeland) from a merger of three companies: Baekeland's General Bakelite Company; the Condensite Company, founded by J.W. Aylesworth; and theFormica (plastic)#HistoryRedmanolChemical Products Company, founded by L.V. Redman.cite bookAmerican Institute of Chemical Engineers StaffTwenty-Five Years of Chemical Engineering ProgressAyer Publishing19772160-8369-0149-5Under director of advertising and public relations Allan Brown, who came to Bakelite from Condensite, Bakelite was aggressively marketed as "The Material of A Thousand Uses."rp58–59cite journalBrownAllanBakelite -- What It IsPlastics19251117, 28–29The Bakelitetrademark, featuring the letter B above theInfinity symbolmathematical symbol for infinity, was filed for as of August 25, 1925, and claimed in use as of December 1, 1924. A wide variety of uses were listed in their trademark applications.cite journalTateA. C.The Protective Power of a Good Trade MarkPlastics19251253

link.target: File:Bakelite color chart 1924 Gifts to Treasure Embed Art Company Jewel only.tif
link.part: Color chart for Bakelite "Jewel" quality colors (cast resin or "Clear Material"), 1924

article.paragraph: The first issue ofPlasticsmagazine, October 1925, featured Bakelite on its cover, and included the article "Bakelite -- What It Is" by Allan Brown. The range of colors available included "black, brown, red, yellow, green, gray, blue, and blends of two or more of these".cite journalCover IllustrationPlastics192511The article emphasized that Bakelite came in various forms. "Bakelite is manufactured in several forms to suit varying requirements. In all these forms the fundamental basis is the initial Bakelite resin. This variety includes Clear Material, for jewelry, smokers' articles, etc.; cement, using in sealing electric light bulbs in metal bases; varnishes, for impregnating electric coils, etc.; lacquers, for protecting the surface of hardware; enamels, for giving resistive coating to industrial equipment; Laminated Bakelite, used for silent gears and insulation; and molding material, from which are formed innumerable articles of utility and beauty. The Molding Material is prepared ordinarily by the impregnation of cellulose substances with the initial 'uncured' resin."rp17In a 1925 report, the United States Tariff Commission hailed the commercial manufacture of synthetic phenolic resin as "distinctly an American achievement", and noted that "the publication of figures, however, would be a virtual disclosure of the production of an individual company."cite bookUnited States Tariff CommissionCensus of dyes and of other synthetic organic chemicals1925U. S. Tariff CommissionWashington, D. C.5934https://books.google.com/books?id31 August 2015

In England Bakelite Limited, a merger of three British phenol formaldehyde resin suppliers (Damard Lacquer Company Limited ofBirmingham, Mouldensite Limited of Darley Dale and Redmanol Chemical Products Company ofLondon) was formed in 1926. A new Bakelite factory opened inTyseley, Birmingham, England around 1928.cite bookTravisAnthony S.Determinants in the evolution of the European chemical industry : 1900-1939 : new technologies, political frameworks, markets and companies1998Kluwer Acad. Publ.Dordrecht9780792348900180https://books.google.com/books?id27 August 2015It was demolished in 1998.

A new factory was opened inBound Brook, New Jersey, in 1931.rp75In 1939 the companies were acquired byUnion CarbideUnion Carbide and Carbon Corporation. Union Carbide's phenolic resin business including the Bakelite and Bakelit registered trademarks are owned byMomentive Specialty Chemicals.

In addition to the original Bakelite material, these companies eventually made a wide range of other products, many of which were marketed under the brand name "Bakelite plastics". These included other types of cast phenolic resins similar toCatalin, and urea-formaldehyde resins, which could be made in brighter colors than polyoxybenzylmethylenglycolanhydride.cite bookAmerican Plastic: A Cultural HistoryMeikleJeffrey L.1995Rutgers University PressNew Brunswick,NJ0-8135-2235-8

Once Baekeland's heat and pressure patents expired in 1927, Bakelite Corporation faced serious competition from other companies. Because molded Bakelite incorporated fillers to give it strength, it tended to be made in concealing dark colors.In 1927, beads, bangles and earrings were produced by theCatalinCompany, through a different process which enabled them to introduce 15 new colors. Translucent jewelry, poker chips and other items made of phenolic resins were introduced in the 1930s or 1940s by the Catalin Company under the Prystal name.cite bookLeshnerLeighCollecting art plastic jewelry : identification and price guide2005KP BooksIola, WI978-087349954511–13https://books.google.com/books?id23 February 2015cite bookKatzSylviaPlastics : designs and materials.1978Studio VistaLondon, Angleterre97802897078386523 February 2015The creation of marbled phenolic resins may also be attributable to the Catalin Company.
article.heading: Synthesis
article.paragraph: Making Bakelite was a multi-stage process. It began with the heating of phenol and formaldehyde in the presence of a catalyst such ashydrochloric acid,zinc chloride, or the baseammonia. This created a liquid condensation product, referred to asBakelite A, which was soluble in alcohol, acetone, or additional phenol. Heated further, the product became partially soluble and could still be softened by heat. Sustained heating resulted in an "insoluble hard gum". However, the high temperatures required to create this tended to cause violent foaming of the mixture, which resulted in the cooled material being porous and breakable. Baekeland's innovative step was to put his "last condensation product" into an egg-shaped "Bakelizer". By heating it under pressure, at about 150 C., Baekeland was able to suppress the foaming that would otherwise occur. The resulting substance was extremely hard and both infusable and insoluble.rp67rp38–39

article.heading: Compression molding
article.paragraph: File:RotorBakelite-2.jpgthumbBakelitedistributorrotorMolded Bakelite forms in a condensation reaction of phenol and formaldehyde, withwood flourorasbestosfiber as a filler, under high pressure and heat in a time frame of a few minutes ofCuring (chemistry)curing. The result is a hard plastic material.cite webhttp://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/podcast/CIIEcompounds/transcripts/bakelite.aspChemistry in its element – bakeliteRoyal Society of Chemistry - RSC.orgCleggBrianMay 4, 2014

Bakelite's molding process had a number of advantages. Bakelite resin could be provided either as powder, or as preformed partially cured slugs, increasing the speed of the casting. Thermosetting resins such as Bakelite required heat and pressure during the molding cycle, but could be removed from the molding process without being cooled, again making the molding process faster. Also, because of the smooth polished surface that resulted, Bakelite objects required less finishing.cite bookVander VoortGeorge F.Metallography, Principles and Practice1984McGraw-HillNew York161503236375–811https://books.google.com/books?id26 February 2015Millions of parts could be duplicated quickly and relatively cheaply.rp42–43
article.heading: Phenolic sheet
article.paragraph: Another market for Bakelite resin was the creation of phenolic sheet materials. Phenolic sheet is a hard, dense material made by applying heat and pressure to layers of paper or glass cloth impregnated with synthetic resin.rp53Cellulosepaper,cottonfabrics,Synthetic fibersynthetic yarnfabrics,Glass (fiber)glass fabricsand unwoven fabrics are all possible materials used in lamination. When heat and pressure are applied,polymerizationtransforms the layers intoThermosetting plasticthermosettingindustrial laminated plastic.cite webBakelitehttp://www.nimrodplastics.com.au/product-bakelite.htmNimrod Plastics26 February 2015

Bakelite phenolic sheet is produced in dozens of commercial grades and with various additives to meet diverse mechanical, electrical and thermal requirements. Some common types include:cite webMicarta ® Laminates – Various Grades Technical Informationhttp://www.professionalplastics.com/professionalplastics/MicartaGrades-DataSheet.pdfProfessional Plastics26 February 2015

list.listitem: Paper reinforcedNational Electrical Manufacturers AssociationNEMAXX per MIL-I-24768 PBGNormal electrical applications, moderate mechanical strength, continuousoperating temperatureofconvert250°F.
Canvas reinforced NEMA C per MIL-I-24768 TYPE FBM NEMA CE per MIL-I-24768 TYPE FBGGood mechanical and impact strength with continuous operating temperature ofconvert250°F.

Linen reinforced NEMA L per MIL-I-24768 TYPE FBI NEMA LE per MIL-I-24768 TYPE FEIGood mechanical and electrical strength. Recommended for intricate high strength parts. Continuous operating temperatureconvert250°F.
Nylon reinforced NEMA N-1 per MIL-I-24768 TYPE NPGSuperior electrical properties under humid conditions, fungus resistant, continuous operating temperature ofconvert160°F.

article.heading: Properties
article.paragraph: Bakelite has a number of important properties. It can be molded very quickly, allowing identical units to be mass-produced. Moldings are smooth, retain their shape and are resistant to heat, scratches, and destructive solvents. It is also resistant to electricity, and prized for its low conductivity. It is not flexible.rp44–45cite bookvan WijkA.J.M.van WijkI.3D Printing with Biomaterials: Towards a Sustainable and Circular Economy2015IOS Press161499486239https://books.google.com/books?id

Phenolic resin products may swell slightly under conditions of extreme humidity or perpetual dampness.cite bookPlastics1952Ministry of SupplyGreat Britainhttps://books.google.com/books?idWhen rubbed or burnt, Bakelite has a distinctive, acrid, sickly-sweet or fishy odor.cite bookMalanowskiGregoryThe Race for Wireless2011Author HouseBloomington, IN978146343750379https://books.google.com/books?id26 February 2015
article.heading: Applications and usage
article.paragraph: These characteristics made Bakelite particularly suitable as a molding compound, an adhesive or binding agent, a varnish, and as a protective coating. Bakelite was particularly suitable for the emerging electrical and automobile industries because of its extraordinarily high resistance to electricity, heat and chemical action.rp44–45

The earliest commercial use of Bakelite in the electrical industry was the molding of tiny insulating bushings the size of mustard seeds, made in 1908 for the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation by Richard W. Seabury of the Boonton Rubber Company.rp43cite journalThe Old TimerI Remember WhenBakelite Review19357324–28Bakelite was soon used for non-conducting parts of telephones, radios and other electrical devices, including bases and sockets for light bulbs and electron tubes, supports for any type of electrical components, automobile distributor caps and other insulators.cite journalBakelite The material of a thousand uses (Advertisement)Popular Science1926March105https://books.google.com/books?id5 August 2015By 1912, it was being used to make billiard balls, since its elasticity and the sound it made were similar to ivory.cite bookLe CouteurPennyBurresonJayNapoleon's buttons : 17 molecules that changed history2003Jeremy P. Tarcher/PenguinNew York9781585423316135–137cite bookLokensgardErickIndustrial plastics : theory and application2010Delmar Cengage LearningClifton Park, NY978-14283607095thhttps://books.google.com/books?id

DuringWorld War I, Bakelite was used widely for machine parts, particularly electrical systems. Important projects included the Liberty Motor,cite bookNavy Department Bureau of Steam EngineeringNotes on Liberty engine ignition system1919Government Printing OfficeWashington, D. C.8, 20https://books.google.com/books?id27 August 2015the wireless telephone and radio phonecite journalHirschWilliam CrawfordRadio Apparatus - What is it made of?Electrical Record and Buyer's Reference192231392-298https://books.google.com/books?id27 August 2015and the use of micarta-bakelite propellors in the NBS-1 bomber and the DH-4B aeroplane.cite journalCarrGardner W.Organization and Activities of Engineering Division of the Army Air ServiceUnited States Air Services1922722–27https://books.google.com/books?idcite bookMumfordJohn KimberlyThe story of bakelite1924Robert L. Stillson Co.New York70–80http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/00391367327 August 2015

Bakelite's availability and ease and speed of molding helped to lower the costs of production and increase product availability so that both telephones and radios became common household consumer goods.rp116–117cite journalBakelite Materials in IndustryBakelite Review19357330–36cite webVintage Bakelite and Catalin Radioshttp://www.collectorsweekly.com/radios/catalin-bakeliteCollectors Weekly6 August 2015It was also very important to the developing automobile industry.cite newsBalinskiBrentManufacturers’ Monthly Material of the Month part 1: Bakelitehttp://www.manmonthly.com.au/features/manufacturers-monthly-material-of-the-month-part-16 August 2015Manufacturer's MonthlySeptember 12, 2014It was soon found in myriad other consumer products ranging from pipe stems and buttons tosaxophonemouthpieces,Brownie (camera)cameras, early machine guns, and appliance casings.cite bookFranklinAdrianCollecting the 20th Century2010UNSW PressSydney48–53https://books.google.com/books?id

Beginning in the 1920s it became a popular material for jewelry.cite bookTortorielloLynLyonsDeborahBakelite jewelry : the art of the carver2008Schiffer Pub.Atglen, PA0764329146DesignerCoco Chanelincluded Bakelite bracelets in hercostume jewelrycollections.cite bookDavidovCorinneDawesGinny RedingtonThe bakelite jewelry book1988Abbeville PressNew York97808965986761strp27–29Designers such asElsa Schiaparelliused it for jewelry and also for specially designed dress buttons.cite journalBrandtAnneBakelite: The Beautiful Plastichttp://www.antiqueshoppefl.com/articles/january07/bakelite.htmAntique Shoppe Newspaper20076 August 2015cite bookCodinaCarlesThe new jewelry : contemporary materials & techniques2005Lark BooksNew York978-1579907341111sthttps://books.google.com/books?id6 August 2015Later,Diana Vreeland, editor ofVogue (magazine)Vogue, was enthusiastic about Bakelite.cite bookGarciaNinaThe one hundred : a guide to the pieces every stylish woman must own2010It BooksNew York, NY978-00616646321stBakelite was also used to make presentation boxes forBreitling SABreitlingwatches. Jewelry designers such asJorge Caicedo Montes De Ocastill use vintage Bakelite materials to make designer jewelry.cite webAbout Ushttp://theartofbakelite.com/pages/about-usThe Art of Bakelite31 August 2015

By 1930, designerPaul T. Franklconsidered Bakelite a "Materia Nova", "expressive of our own age".rp107By the 1930s, Bakelite was used for game pieces like chessmen, poker chips,cite bookClarkTessaBakelite style1997AppleLondon1850768633dominoescite bookKelleyJennifer A.Great book of domino games1999Sterling Pub.New York0806942592andMah Jongsets.cite bookIsraelAnnSwainGregMah Jong The Art & History of the Game.2014Tuttle PubChapter 5: Bakelite and Catalin9784805313237cite bookRepJelteThe great mahjong book : history, lore and play2007Tuttle PubNorth Clarendon, VT08048371981sthttps://books.google.com/books?idKitchenware made with Bakelite, including canisters and tableware, were promoted for their resistance to heat and to chipping.cite bookMauzyBarbara E.Bakelite in the kitchen2001Schiffer Pub.Atglen, PA07643137972ndcite newsDanielsMaryOnce Touted As `Kitchen Jewelry,' Bakelite Flatware Is Making A Comebackhttp://articles.chicagotribune.com/1993-09-19/news/9309190213_1_phenolic-colorful-sets6 August 2015Chicago TribuneSeptember 19, 1993In the mid-30s Northland marketed a line of skis with a black 'Ebonite' base, a coating of Bakelite.cite journalMasiaSethMilestones and detours in ski designSkiing Heritage Journal2004March18–22, 36https://books.google.com/books?id5 August 2015cite bookBrydenAllisonFrom tip to tail1999Aspen Historical SocietyAspen, CO.http://www.archiveaspen.org/documents/FromTiptoTailsearchable.pdfBy 1935, it was used inRickenbackersolid-body electric guitars. Performers such asJerry Byrdloved the tone of Bakelite guitars but found them difficult to keep in tune.cite bookBaconTonyDayPaulThe Rickenbacker book : [a complete history of Rickenbacker electric guitars]1994GPI BooksSan Francisco978-087930329731–361st Americanhttps://books.google.com/books?id

DuringWorld War II, Bakelite was used in a variety of wartime equipment including pilot goggles and field telephones.cite bookGrafJohn AdamsWarman's World War II Collectibles Identification and Price Guide.2014Krause Pubns Inc978-1440240706https://books.google.com/books?idIt was also used for patriotic wartime jewelry.cite webHome Front Friday: Bakelite for the Fighthttp://www.nww2m.com/2015/04/bakelite-for-the-fight/The National WWII Museum6 August 2015cite bookTanenbaumCaroleFabulous fakes : a passion for vintage of costume jewelry2006ArtisanNew York978-157965292070https://books.google.com/books?id6 August 2015In 1943, the thermosetting phenolic resin was even considered for the manufacture ofpenny (U.S. coin)coins, due to a shortage of traditional material. Bakelite and other non-metal materials were tested for usage for theCent (United States coin)one cent coinin the US before theUnited States MintMintsettled on1943 steel centzinc-coated steel.J2051/P2073USPatterns.com. Retrieved July 28, 2006The New Yorker.Penny Dreadful. David Owen. March 31, 2008.

In 1947, Dutch art forgerHan van Meegerenwas convicted of forgery, after chemist and curatorPaul B. Coremansproved that a purportedJohannes VermeerVermeercontained Bakelite, which van Meegeren had used as a paint hardener.cite bookWilliamsRobert C.The forensic historian : using science to reexamine the past2013M.E. SharpeArmonk, N.Y.978-0765636621https://books.google.com/books?id27 August 2015

Bakelite was sometimes used as a substitute for metal in the magazine, pistol grip, fore grip, hand guard, and butt stock of firearms. Some earlyAK-74rifles have been identified as using Bakelite, but most were made with AG-S4, commonly mistaken for Bakelite.cite bookKokalisPeterWeapons Tests And Evaluations: The Best Of Soldier Of Fortune2001Paladin Press45, 49

By the late 1940s, newer materials were superseding Bakelite in many areas.Phenolic resinPhenolicsare less frequently used in general consumer products today due to their cost and complexity of production and their brittle nature. They still appear in some applications where their specific properties are required, such as small precision-shaped components, molded disc brake cylinders, saucepan handles, electrical plugs, switches and parts for electrical irons.,as well as in the area of inexpensive board and tabletop games produced in China, India and Hong Kong.cite webBakelite Market - Global Industry Analysis, Size, Share, Trends, Analysis, Growth And Forecast, 2012 - 2018http://www.transparencymarketresearch.com/bakelite-market.htmlTransparency Market Research6 August 2015Items such asbilliard balls, dominoes and pieces for games likechess,checkers, andbackgammonare constructed of Bakelite for its look, durability, fine polish, weight, and sound. Common dice are sometimes made of Bakelite for weight and sound, but the majority are made of a thermoplastic polymer such asacrylonitrile butadiene styrene(ABS).Bakelite continues to be used for wire insulation, brake pads and related automotive components, and industrial electrical-related applications. Bakelite stock is still manufactured and produced in sheet, rod and tube form for industrial applications in theelectronics,power generationandaerospaceindustries, and under a variety of commercial brand names.

Phenolic resins have been commonly used in ablative heat shields.cite bookEllisBryanSmithRayPolymers a property database2009CRC Press/Taylor & Francis GroupBoca Raton14200057073722ndhttps://books.google.com/books?idSoviet heatshields for ICBM warheads and spacecraft reentry consisted of asbestos textolite, impregnated with Bakelite.Roads to Space: an oral history of the Soviet space program. Aviation Week Group (1995) ISBN 0076070956Bakelite is also used in the mounting of metal samples inmetallography.cite webhttp://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/StructuresMaterials/ASG/MetLab/mounting.htmlMetallographic Preparation MountingNASAMay 13, 2008
article.heading: Collectable status
article.paragraph: Bakelite items, particularly jewelry and radios, have become a popularcollectable.The termBakeliteis sometimes used in the resale market to indicate various types of early plastics, includingCatalinwhich may be brightly colored, as well as items made of Bakelite material.cite webCyclebackDavidBakelite and catalin: Collectible early plasticshttps://cycleback.wordpress.com/2013/01/31/bakelite-and-catalin-phenol-formaldehyde-identifying-the-popular-early-plastics/Looking at Art, Artifacts and Ideas6 August 2015
article.heading: Patents
article.paragraph: TheUnited States Patent and Trademark Officegranted Baekeland a patent for a "Method of making insoluble products of phenol and formaldehyde" on December 7, 1909.Producing hard, compact, insoluble and infusable condensation products of phenols and formaldehyde marked the beginning of the modern plastics industry.Baekeland, Leo H (December 7, 1909) "Method of making insoluble products of phenol and formaldehyde"US Patent942699
article.heading: Similar plastics

list.listitem: Catalinanother phenolic resin, similar to Bakelite, but with different mineral fillers that allowed the production of light colors
Condensite a similar material of the age having much the same properties, characteristics, and uses
Galalithanother early plastic, derived from milk
Micartaearly composite insulating plate that used Bakelite as a binding agent, trademarked 1912 by Westinghouse Elec. & Mfg Co.
Novotextbrand name for cotton textile-phenolic resin
